rationale: This restricted range species is known only from three locations where it has been collected from coral reef, seagrass, sponges, rocky cliffs and boulders on large patches of white sand between zero to 20 m depth. Its estimated EOO is 10,241 km2 and its AOO is 1,012 km2, which meets the thresholds for Vulnerable under B1 and B2. It may be impacted by degradation of coral habitat due to anchoring of super tankers in Saba Bank as well as a directly observed coral cover loss of 14.6% over a 41 year period (1970-2011) off St. Croix. It also may be susceptible to predation by the invasive lionfish throughout its entire range, however, species-specific information is not yet known. Therefore, it is listed as VU B1ab(iii)+B2ab(iii).
habitat: Specimens were collected from low coral and sponges on white sand bottom, off rocky cliffs, from boulders on large patches of white sand, and short seagrass at edge of sand patches (Greenfield 1993).
threats:
This species may be impacted by coral reef degradation. The Saba Bank area where it has been found is a locality where supertankers anchor and destroy coral reefs. Between 1970-2011 (41 years), an overall 59% decline in coral cover was directly observed in the Caribbean, which was caused by anthropogenic stressors, Diadema antillarum decline, and coral disease. Location specific estimates in coral decline: no long-term data available for Saba Bank; 14.6% decline off St. Croix between 1970-2011; no data available for St. Barthelemy (Jackson et al. 2014). The area of total coral cover within its range is 47 km2, and St. Croix represents 19% of this area (9 km2). However, this species has been collected from other habitat types and is therefore not likely dependent on live coral reef. Coral habitat (47 km2) comprises 5% of its known extent between 0-20 m depth (1,012 km2).  

It may be threatened by the invasive lionfish, which is known to inhabit areas throughout its entire range. It is easily targeted by the lionfish given its small, shallow body and demersal habits (Green and Cote 2014). Due to the lionfish's ability to consume a variety of fishes smaller than 15 cm, both adults and juveniles of this species are likely consumed. It has not yet been recorded from a lionfish gut analysis, however, 13 Gobiidae spp. have been documented. In the Bahamas, a 65% decline in lionfish prey biomass over a period of two years was observed (species-specific data are not available at this time) (Green et al. 2012).
population: This very rare species was previously known from only five specimens taken at Saint Barthelemy in 1965, one from Saba Bank (Williams et al. 2010) and one from St. Croix in 2001.
range: Psilotris boehlkei is known only from St. Croix (J. Van Tassell pers. comm. 2015), St. Barthelemy (Greenfield 1993), and Saba Bank Atoll (Williams et al. 2010) in the Caribbean Sea. It has an estimated extent of occurrence (EOO) of 10,241 km2 (based on a minimum convex polygon drawn around the extent of its range on a zero to 20 m bathymetric layer). It has an estimated area of occupancy (AOO) of 1,012 km2 (calculated by clipping the distribution polygon to the zero to 20 m bathymetric layer extracted from ETOPO).
useTrade: This species is not used.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures in place for this species. Further research is needed into the distribution, habitats and ecology and threats to this species.

rationale: Tigrigobius redimiculus is known only from patch reefs in the proximity of Veracruz, Mexico and Isla Lobos. As this species is not a live coral obligate, but may be relatively common where it occurs on live brain coral and coral rubble. Considering it is not a live coral obligate, its EOO and AOO is estimated as 11,861 and 1,606 km2, respectively. However, coral reef declined by at least 17% over a 34 year period off Veracruz and unquantified degradation is also occurring off Tuxpan-Lobos, which causes its total area of available live coral habitat to be calculated as 32 km2. Pollution and coastal development are degrading and potentially destroying coral reefs in both locations. Given this information, it conservatively qualifies for Vulnerable under B1 and B2. It is likely susceptible to predation by the invasive Lionfish, which now occurs throughout its entire range. An overall 65% decline in prey biomass was directly observed over a period of two years in the Bahamas. However, species-specific decline nor generation length are available at this time. Therefore, it is listed as VU B1ab(iii)+B2ab(iii). Further research is needed on the impact of habitat degradation and lionfish predation.
habitat: Tigrigobius redimiculus is typically found on brightly illuminated surfaces of either living boulder brain coral (Colpophyllia natans) or algae encrusted covered coral remnants in shallow waters between three to eight metres depth near reefs (Taylor and Akins 2007). Its maximum size is 1.7 cm SL.
threats: Tigrigobius redimiculus is threatened by loss of coral reef habitat. It inhabits degraded coral reef systems, including dead coral and algae encrusted coral (L. Tornabene pers. comm. 2014), so live coral may not be crucial to the survival of this species. Between 1965-1999 (34 years), a 17% decline in coral cover was directly observed off Veracruz (Jackson et al. 2014). It is considered endemic to the Tuxpan-Lobos and Veracruz reef systems which are threatened by heavy anthropogenic impacts such as accidental fuel spills from the nearby Port of Tuxpan, commercial shipping activity that enters directly through the marine protected area, and contamination from heavy metals, faeces, fertilizers and pesticide pollutants out of the Tuxpan River (Ortiz-Lozano 2012, Gandara et al. 2013). The Mexican government has recently been seeking to expand the Port of Veracruz onto the reef area, which would involve direct removal of reef habitat (Ortiz-Lozano et al. 2013). There have also been significant declines in Acroporid corals with no sign of recovery and a high prevalence of disease on stony corals (Rangel-Avalos et al. 2007). This species may be easily targeted for predation by the invasive lionfish given its small, shallow body and demersal habits (Green and Cote 2014). Due to the lionfish's ability to consume a variety of fishes smaller than 15 cm, both adults and juveniles of this species are likely consumed. In the Bahamas, a 65% decline in lionfish prey biomass over a period of two years was observed (Green et al. 2012).
population: Tigrigobius redimiculus is commonly observed.
range: Tigrigobius redimiculus is distributed in the western Atlantic on the western Gulf of Mexico Mexican reef systems from Isla De Lobos (21°29.36'N, 97°13.53'W) south to Isla Verde off Veracruz (19°11.88'N, 96°04.12'W) (Taylor and Akins 2007). A record of T. macrodon from Coatzacoalcos is likely a misidentification of T. redimiculus (L. Tornabene pers. comm. 2014). It has an estimated extent of occurrence (EOO) of 8,409 km2 (based on a minimum convex polygon drawn around the extent of its range on a coral reef layer). It has an estimated area of occupancy (AOO) of 32 km2 (calculated by clipping the distribution polygon to the coral reef layer from WCMC 2013). Between 1965-1999 (34 years), a 17% decline in coral cover was directly observed off Veracruz (Jackson et al. 2014). The Veracruz Reef System constitutes 22 km2 of its total range in the Gulf. Quantified data are not available for the Tuxpan-Lobos Reef System, however, declines are suspected there as well due to increased port activity and pollution from river runoff (Gandara et al. 2013). However, this may be an underestimate of its AOO as this species is not a live coral obligate. Given this uncertainty, a more conservative estimate of its EOO and AOO may be 11,861 and 1,606 km2, respectively (calculated by clipping the distribution polygon to the zero to 10 m bathymetric layer from ETOPO).
useTrade: Tigrigobius redimiculus is not utilized.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures in place. The Sistema Arrecifal Veracruzano has been designated as a national park since 1992 and a UNESCO Biosphere Reserve since 2006, however, there is no effective management plan in place. Furthermore, the Mexican government has been seeking to reduce the size of the protected area in order to expand the Port of Veracruz onto the reef area (Ortiz-Lozano et al. 2013). There is also a marine protected area around Isla Lobos, with a management plan in press, but there is limited enforcement (T. Camarena-Luhrs pers. comm. 2014).

rationale: This species is known only from four localities and can be common where it occurs over live coral. Its estimated AOO is 2,622 km<sup>2</sup>, which could contribute to a listing of Near Threatened under B2. It may be impacted by loss of coral, however, coral monitoring studies off Cuba, the Bahamas, and the Turks and Caicos do not indicate any significant declines at this time. It is therefore listed as Least Concern with a recommendation to monitor the status of its habitat.
habitat: This reef-associated species is found on live coral.  It is a cleaner, removing ectoparasites from other fishes.  This species is monogamous (Whiteman and Côté 2004).  It has been reared in captivity (Breeder's Registry 1997).
threats: This species is dependent on coral and may be impacted by coral loss. Between 1970-2011 (41 years), an overall 59% decline in coral cover was directly observed in the Caribbean, which was caused by anthropogenic stressors, Diadema antillarum decline, and coral disease. Between 1993-2011, coral cover was stable in the Bahamas. There has been a generally increasing trend in coral cover off northern and southwestern Cuba. No long-term data is available for the Turks and Caicos, though coral cover was recorded to be about 18% in 1999 (Jackson et al. 2014). The level of collection for the aquarium trade needs additional investigation.
population: This species is relatively common within its habitat.
range: This species is distributed in the western Atlantic from the Bahamas, Turks and Caicos, and northeastern and southwestern Cuba (R. Robertson pers. comm. 2014). It has an estimated area of occupancy (AOO) of 2,622 km<sup>2</sup> (calculated by clipping the distribution polygon to the WCMC 2013 coral layer and the zero to 50 m bathymetric layer from ETOPO).
useTrade: This species is found in the aquarium trade.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures in place. Additional information is needed on the severity of possible threats.

rationale: This species is endemic to the Gulf of Mexico where it is restricted to two Mexican reef systems: Tuxpan-Lobos and Veracruz, Mexico. It can be somewhat common and is dependent on coral reefs. Its estimated EOO is 8,409 km<sup>2 </sup>and its AOO is 32 km<sup>2</sup>. There has been a directly observed 17% decline in coral cover off Veracruz over a period of 34 years. Both reef locations are threatened by pollution and coastal development, which are degrading and potentially destroying coral reefs. Given this information, it qualifies for Vulnerable under B1 and Endangered under B2. It is likely susceptible to predation by the invasive Lionfish, which now occurs throughout its entire range. An overall 65% decline in prey biomass was directly observed over a period of two years in the Bahamas. However, species-specific decline is not available at this time. Therefore, it is listed as EN B2ab(iii). This species should be monitored as further loss of coral could quickly cause this species to qualify for CR.
habitat: Elacatinus jarocho can be found between three to 25 m depth on high profile coral reefs typically dominated by Montastrea cavernosa, M. annularis, Colpophyllia natans, and skeletal reef framework. This species and E. atronasus from the Bahamas are the only two in the genus that school in the water column. Small to large aggregations (12–60 individuals) are normally found close to the reef near high profile corals or overhangs. Such reef structure presumably provides shelter from direct sunlight because aggregations were usually observed in darker, shaded areas. Unlike E. atronasus, individuals of this species were never observed stationary on any substrate, but rather hovered continuously about five to 25 cm above the reef frequently in association with Coryphopterus hyalinus or C. personatus. It has not been observed to clean other species or interact in other symbiotic relationships. Small and large individuals coexisted in the same aggregations and did not display territorial or hierarchical behaviours (Taylor and Akins 2007). The recorded maximum size is 2.72 cm SL.
threats: Elacatinus jarocho is likely impacted by loss of coral reef habitat. Between 1965-1999 (34 years), a 17% decline in coral cover was directly observed off Veracruz (Jackson et al. 2014). It is considered endemic to the Tuxpan-Lobos and Veracruz reef systems which are threatened by heavy anthropogenic impacts such as accidental fuel spills from the nearby Port of Tuxpan, commercial shipping activity that enters directly through the marine protected area, and contamination from heavy metals, faeces, fertilizers and pesticide pollutants out of the Tuxpan River (Ortiz-Lozano 2012, Gandara et al. 2013). The Mexican government has recently been seeking to expand the Port of Veracruz onto the reef area, which would involve direct removal of reef habitat (Ortiz-Lozano et al. 2013). There have also been significant declines in Acroporid corals with no sign of recovery and a high prevalence of disease on stony corals (Rangel-Avalos et al. 2007). This species may be easily targeted for predation by the invasive lionfish given its small, shallow body and demersal habits (Green and Cote 2014). Due to the lionfish's ability to consume a variety of fishes smaller than 15 cm, both adults and juveniles of this species are likely consumed. In the Bahamas, a 65% decline in lionfish prey biomass over a period of two years was observed (Green et al. 2012).
population: Elacatinus jarocho is relatively common. Small to large aggregations of 12-60 individuals are found near high profile coral overhangs.
range: Elacatinus jarocho is known only from the Tuxpan-Lobos and Veracruz reef systems off Mexico in the Gulf of Mexico and may be present at reefs between these two areas. Specimens were observed as far north as Isla De Lobos and as far south as Anton Lizardo (Taylor and Akins 2007). It has an estimated extent of occurrence (EOO) of 8,409 km2 (based on a minimum convex polygon drawn around the extent of its range on a coral reef layer). It has an estimated area of occupancy (AOO) of 32 km2 (calculated by clipping the distribution polygon to the coral reef layer from WCMC 2013). Between 1965-1999 (34 years), a 17% decline in coral cover was directly observed off Veracruz (Jackson et al. 2014). The Veracruz Reef System constitutes 22 km2 of its total range in the Gulf. Quantified data are not available for the Tuxpan-Lobos Reef System, however, declines are suspected there as well due to increased port activity and pollution from river runoff (Gandara et al. 2013).
useTrade: Elacatinus jarocho is not utilized.
conservationActions: This species is currently known only from within a protected area. More information is needed on population, habitat status and impact of major threats. The Sistema Arrecifal Veracruzano has been designated as a national park since 1992 and a UNESCO Biosphere Reserve since 2006, however, there is no effective management plan in place. Furthermore, the Mexican government has been seeking to reduce the size of the protected area in order to expand the Port of Veracruz onto the reef area (Ortiz-Lozano et al. 2013). There is also a marine protected area around Isla Lobos, with a management plan in press, but there is limited enforcement (T. Camarena-Luhrs pers. comm. 2014).

rationale:
This widely distributed species can be abundant where it occurs in coral reef habitat and is often associated with sponges. Its estimated global AOO is less than 2,000 km2 and is severely fragmented due to its preference for Montastrea annularis. In addition, the larval retention of this species is very localized and therefore, has a very low probability of reseeding depleted subpopulations. Given this information, it meets the threshold for Vulnerable under B2. It is threatened by the loss of coral reef habitat throughout its entire range (at least 20% over a 41 year period). It has been documented in the diet of the invasive lionfish, which may constitute a further threat to its population, however, further research is needed as cleaner gobies are generally not considered preferred lionfish prey items. Therefore, it is listed as VU B2ab(iii) globally.

In the Gulf of Mexico, its AOO is 25 km2 and its EOO is 2,915 km2. Its separate subpopulation in the Gulf of Mexico off Veracruz is threatened by pollution and coastal development, which are degrading and potentially destroying coral reefs. Given this information, it meets Vulnerable under D2 and the thresholds for Endangered under B1 and B2. The invasive lionfish may constitute a further threat to its population, however, further research is needed. It has been documented in the diet, but cleaner gobies are generally not considered preferred lionfish prey items. Therefore, in the Gulf of Mexico it is listed as EN B1ab(iii)+B2ab(iii). This species should be monitored as further loss of coral could quickly cause it to regionally qualify for CR.
habitat: Elacatinus prochilos is a reef-associated cleaner goby that occurs in groups near coral heads with a preference for Montastrea annularis and sponges (Lieske and Myers 1994, Wilson 1998, Dennis et al. 2004). At coral cleaning stations it is more frequently solitary or found in small groups, while groups of up to 40 individuals were observed on sponge cleaning stations. It forms dominance hierarchies based on body size. Differences in substrate are linked to marked differences in social behaviour, cleaning activity and diet, with gobies on sponges cleaning less than gobies on corals (Whiteman and Côté 2004). Fish that range in size from six to 34 mm can be found co-occurring on the same substrate (Wilson 2005). This species is monogamous (Whiteman and Côté 2004) and sexes can be distinguished by the shape of the urogenital papilla (Thresher 1984). It consumes Gnathiid isopod larvae and caligid copepods in addition to fish scales, mucous, coral polyps and sponges. It is thought to consume less ectoparasites than other Caribbean and Pacific members of the genus (Arnal and Côte 2000). It does not undergo ontogenetic habitat shifts except when reproductive individuals leave live coral heads and build nests in small holes within the reef; however, young fish and fish of reproductive size are often present on coral heads together (Wilson 2005, Wilson pers. comm. 2011).
threats: Elacatinus prochilos is likely impacted by loss of coral reef habitat. There was an overall 59% decline in coral cover in the entire Caribbean between 1970-2011, and specifically an average of approximately 20% within the range of this species (Jackson et al. 2014). Between 1965-1999 (34 years), a 17% decline in coral cover was directly observed off Veracruz (Jackson et al. 2014). This area is impacted by commercial shipping activity that enters directly through the marine protected area and runoff contamination from heavy metals, faeces, fertilizers and pesticide pollutants (Ortiz-Lozano 2012). The Mexican government has recently been seeking to expand the Port of Veracruz onto the reef area, which would involve direct removal of reef habitat (Ortiz-Lozano et al. 2013). There have also been significant declines in Acroporid corals with no sign of recovery and a high prevalence of disease on stony corals (Rangel-Avalos et al. 2007). It has been recorded in the diet of the invasive Lionfish in the Mexican Caribbean, however, this is likely not a major threat considering lionfish uncommonly consume cleaner fishes (Villasenor-Derbez and Herrera-Perez 2014, Green and Cote 2014).
population: Elacatinus prochilos is abundant. Populations have been described as unstructured (Whiteman and Côté 2004, Wilson 2005). Despite an extended pelagic larval duration of 21 days, the retention of larvae of a sister and co-occurring species (E. evelynae) is almost exclusively localized. This indicates that the potential for subpopulations to receive propagules from elsewhere is very low (Taylor and Hellberg 2003).
range: Elacatinus prochilos is distributed in the western Atlantic from Veracruz, Mexico in the Gulf of Mexico and in the Caribbean from Jamaica along the Antilles to Tobago and from Quintana Roo, Mexico to Roatan, Honduras and Las Isles de Cisne (R. Robertson pers. comm. 2014). It is known from three potentially widely separated subpopulations (Colin 2010). It has an estimated area of occupancy (AOO) of 3,214 km2 (calculated by clipping the distribution polygon to the coral reef layer from WCMC 2013). Between 1970-2011 (41 years), the following coral cover declines were directly observed within its range: 17% Veracruz (1965-1999), 18% USVI, 30% Puerto Rico, 6% Barbados, 28% Jamaica, and 16.5% Belize (average 20%). Furthermore, considering it specifically prefers the boulder star coral, Montastrea annularis, its AOO is therefore assumed to be less than 2,000 km2. The subpopulation in the Gulf of Mexico is restricted to the Veracruz Reef System, where its AOO is 25 km2 and its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 2,915 km2. Between 1965-1999 (34 years), a 17% decline in coral cover was directly observed off Veracruz (Jackson et al. 2014).
useTrade: Elacatinus prochilos has been used as an indicator of habitat quality (Wilson 2005). It could possibly be targeted for the aquarium trade.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures in place.

rationale: This species is widespread and can be abundant where it occurs over coral reef. It may be impacted by coral degradation, however, this is only expected to occur on a localized basis at this time. The three colour morphs that occur under Elacatinus evelynae may represent separate species, however, further taxonomic research is needed. It is therefore listed as Least Concern.
habitat: This species inhabits coral reefs in clear waters, preferably in oceanic, insular areas. It is found near coral heads occurring in monogamous pairs (Whiteman and Côté 2004). Social monogamy in E. evelynae appears to result from the benefits associated with sequestering a large, high-quality mate (Whiteman and Côté 2003). This species is a cleaner (Lieske and Myers 1994) which feeds on the ectoparasites of fishes (Randall 1996). Twenty-four client species were recorded for Elacatinus evelynae in a 110-h study conducted off St. Croix in the Caribbean (Johnson and Ruben 1988). It feeds on coral polyps, sponges, free-living copepods and gnathiid isopod larvae (Arnal and Côté 2000). It has been reared in captivity (Moe 1992). Females produce demersal adhesive eggs which they attach to the roof of a small cavity within a coral head or the reef itself. After spawning, the male tends and guards the eggs until hatching, usually five to six days later (Thresher 1984). The sexes have the same colouration and gross morphology, but can be distinguished in the field by the shape of the urogenital papilla.
threats: This species is dependent on coral and is therefore vulnerable to coral loss. Between 1970-2011 (41 years), an overall 59% decline in coral cover was directly observed in the Caribbean, which was caused by anthropogenic stressors, Diadema antillarum decline, and coral disease (Jackson et al. 2014). The level of collection for the aquarium trade needs additional investigation.
population: This species has been called abundant, although  not as abundant as E. prochilos which occurs in similar habitats (Arnal and Côté 2000).
range:
This species has three colour morphs, each with a different distribution. The overall distribution of this species is in the western Atlantic from the Bahamas, northeastern and southwestern Cuba, throughout the Antilles, and from Quintana Roo, Mexico to Islas Providencia and San Andres (Colombia). It has also been recorded in the Gulf of Mexico near New Port Richey, Florida, and in the Caribbean from the Aves Islands (Venezuela), and Kusapin, Panama (R. Robertson pers. comm. 2014).

The yellow-blue morph is found in central and southern Bahamas through much of the eastern Caribbean (Bimini, west side of the Grand Bahama Bank, Berry Islands, Grand Bahama, San Salvador, Acklins Island, Crooked Island, south end of Long Island, Hogsty Reef, Caicos Bank, Turks Bank, Puerto Rico, Virgin Islands, Lesser Antilles, Barbados, Isla Margarita, Los Roques, Bonaire and Curacao). The yellow morph is found in northern and eastern Bahamas (Little Bahama Bank, New Providence, Exuma chain, Eleuthera, Berry Islands, northern Andros Islands, north end of Long Island). The white morph is found off Navassa Island, the Mona Channel, between Puerto Rico and Hispaniola, and west across much of the western Caribbean to Swan Island and lsla Providencia (Colin 2010). Victor (2014) considers its presence in the Cayman Islands as doubtful.

It has an estimated area of occupancy (AOO) of 4,425 km2 (calculated by clipping the distribution polygon to the WCMC 2013 coral layer and the zero to 50 m bathymetric layer from ETOPO).
useTrade: This species can be found in the aquarium trade. Captive bred individuals and hybrids are available to aquarists.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures in place. Further research is needed on the impact of coral cover loss on this species.

rationale: Lythrypnus heterochroma is widely distributed and occurs in coral reef habitat. Its estimated AOO is 2,144 km2, which could contribute to a listing of Near Threatened under B2. There has been an estimated average 16.5% decline directly observed in coral cover between 1970-2011 in 41% of its range and no significant change in 50% of its range. Degradation of its coral reef habitat may be cause for concern, however, it is not considered a threat to its global population at this time. It may also be threatened by the invasive lionfish, which occurs throughout its entire range. It has not yet been recorded from a lionfish gut analysis, however, other members of its genus and family have. In the Bahamas, a 65% decline in lionfish prey biomass over a period of two years was observed, but species-specific data are not available at this time. Therefore, it is listed as Least Concern. Further research is needed on the impacts of lionfish predation and habitat degradation.
habitat: Lythrypnus heterochroma inhabits isolated patch reefs surrounded by white sand (Böhlke and Chaplin 1993). It is most abundant in dropoff and spur and groove habitats (Greenfield and Johnson 1999). Fishes of this genus are simultaneously hermaphroditic (St. Mary 1998).
threats:
Some subpopulations may be impacted by loss of coral habitat. Between 1970-2011 (41 years), an overall 59% decline in coral cover was directly observed in the Caribbean, which was caused by anthropogenic stressors, Diadema antillarum decline, and coral disease. Location specific estimates in coral decline: no significant change in the Bahamas between 1993-2011; 4-12% decline in Cayman Islands between 1988-2011; average 28% decline off Jamaica between 1970-2011; no data available for Haiti; 16.5% decline off Belize between 1970-2011; 15.6% decline in the San Andres Islands between 1992-2006; no data available for Cartagena, Colombia (Jackson et al. 2014). The combined area off Belize, the Cayman Islands, San Andres Islands, and Jamaica is 876 km2, which represents 41% of its total range. Therefore, there has been an estimated average 16.5% decline in coral cover between 1970-2011 over 41% of its range and no significant change in 50% of its range (1,066 km2 in the Bahamas). 

This species may be threatened by the invasive lionfish, which is known to inhabit areas throughout its entire range. It may be easily targeted by the lionfish given its small, shallow body and demersal habits (Green and Cote 2014). Due to the lionfish's ability to consume a variety of fishes smaller than 15 cm, both adults and juveniles of this species are likely consumed. It has not yet been recorded from a lionfish gut analysis, however, Lythrypnus minimus (Valdez-Moreno et al. 2012) and L. spilus (Green et al. 2012) have and 13 total Gobiidae spp. have been documented. In the Bahamas, a 65% decline in lionfish prey biomass over a period of two years was observed (species-specific data are not available at this time) (Green et al. 2012).
population: Lythrypnus heterochroma was nineteenth in abundance of all gobiids sampled in a survey conducted off Honduras and Belize (Greenfield and Johnson 1999). It is not common in museum collections.
range: Lythrypnus heterochroma has been recorded in the western Atlantic from the Bahamas, Cayman Islands, Jamaica, Haiti, Belize, the San Andres Islands (Colombia), and near Cartagena, Colombia (Eschmeyer 1998). It does not occur in the Gulf of Mexico (R. Robertson pers. comm. 2014). It has an estimated area of occupancy (AOO) of 2,144 km2 (calculated by clipping the distribution polygon to the WCMC 2013 coral layer and a zero to 25 m bathymetric layer from ETOPO).
useTrade: Lythrypnus heterochroma is not utilized.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures in place.

rationale: This widely distributed, cryptic species is uncommonly recorded. It occurs on hard bottoms including coral and rocky reef. It has been documented as susceptible to predation by the invasive lionfish, which now occurs throughout the entire range of this species. An overall 65% decline in prey biomass was directly observed over a period of two years in the Bahamas. However, species-specific decline nor generation length are available at this time. Therefore, it is listed as Least Concern with a recommendation to monitor the impact of lionfish predation.
habitat: This reef-associated species inhabits dropoff and spur and groove coral reef habitats (Greenfield and Johnson 1999). Off North Carolina, it occurred only on offshore hard bottoms in depths > 15 m and was considered a rarely encountered, cryptic species (Ross and Rhode 2004). It is hermaphroditic (St. Mary 1998).
threats: Lythrypnus spilus is associated with coral reef habitat and may be locally impacted by its degradation. It has been identified as a prey item of the invasive Lionfish in the Bahamas and likely in the remainder of its range (Green et al. 2012, Cote et al. 2013, Green and Cote 2014). This species is easily targeted by the lionfish given its small, shallow body and demersal habits (Green and Cote 2014). Due to the lionfish's ability to consume a variety of fishes smaller than 15 cm, both adults and juveniles of this species are likely consumed. In the Bahamas, a 65% decline in lionfish prey biomass over a period of two years was observed (species-specific data are not available at this time) (Green et al. 2012).
population: This cryptic species is rarely encountered off North Carolina. It was ranked seventeenth in overall abundance in a survey conducted off Belize and Honduras (Greenfield and Johnson 1999).
range: Lythrypnus spilus is distributed in the western Atlantic from North Carolina south along the U.S. coast, Bermuda, the Bahamas, in the Gulf of Mexico from the Florida Keys, Flower Garden Banks, and Alacranes Reef off Mexico, north-central Cuba, in the Caribbean from Grand Cayman Island to St. Kitts and Nevis, Barbados,Tobago, and along Central and South America from southern Belize, Providencia and San Andres Islands (Colombia), and Panama (Bocas del Toro) to Colombia (Santa Marta). It has also been recorded from Curacao and Bonaire (Ross and Rhode 2004, R. Robertson pers. comm. 2014).
useTrade: Lythrypnus spilus is not utilized.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures in place.

rationale: This species is not commonly found, but is widely distributed where it occurs over coral reef habitat. Its estimated AOO is 1,218 km2, which meets the threshold for Vulnerable under B2. There has been an estimated average 17% decline directly observed in coral cover between 1970-2011 in 47% of its range and no significant change in at least 52% of its range. Degradation of its coral reef habitat may be cause for concern, however, it is not considered a threat to its global population at this time. It has not yet been recorded from a lionfish gut analysis, however, other members of its genus and family have. In the Bahamas, a 65% decline in lionfish prey biomass over a period of two years was observed, but species-specific data are not available at this time. There are no major threats. It is therefore listed as Least Concern.
habitat: This reef-associated species inhabits isolated patch reefs surrounded by fine white sand (Böhlke and Chaplin 1993, Smith-Vaniz et al. 2006). Fishes of this genus are simultaneously hermaphroditic (St. Mary 1998).
threats:
Some subpopulations may be impacted by loss of coral habitat. Between 1970-2011 (41 years), an overall 59% decline in coral cover was directly observed in the Caribbean, which was caused by anthropogenic stressors, Diadema antillarum decline, and coral disease. Location specific estimates in coral decline: no significant change in the Bahamas between 1993-2011; 4-12% decline in Cayman Islands between 1988-2011; average 28% decline off Jamaica between 1970-2011; no data available for Haiti; average 18% decline in the U.S. Virgin Islands between 1970-2011; 16.5% decline off Belize between 1970-2011; no significant change off Isla de Providencia between 1999-2006; no significant change off Colombia (Santa Marta) between 1994-2005 (Jackson et al. 2014). The combined area off Belize, USVI, Cayman Islands, and Jamaica is 575 km2, which represents 47% of its total range. Therefore, there has been an estimated average 17% decline in coral cover between 1970-2011 over 47% of its range and no significant change in 52% of its range (632 km2 in the Bahamas, Isla de Providencia, and Santa Marta).

It may be threatened by the invasive lionfish, which is known to inhabit areas throughout its entire range. It may be easily targeted by the lionfish given its small, shallow body and demersal habits (Green and Cote 2014). Due to the lionfish's ability to consume a variety of fishes smaller than 15 cm, both adults and juveniles of this species are likely consumed. It has not yet been recorded from a lionfish gut analysis, however, Lythrypnus minimus (Valdez-Moreno et al. 2012) and L. spilus (Green et al. 2012) have and 13 total Gobiidae spp. have been documented. In the Bahamas, a 65% decline in lionfish prey biomass over a period of two years was observed (species-specific data are not available at this time) (Green et al. 2012).
population: This species was not frequently collected during surveys of Belize and Honduras (Greenfield and Johnson 1999). This species was also considered rare during surveys of cryptic fauna at Buck Island National Park, Saint Croix (Smith-Vaniz et al. 2006).
range: This species has been recorded in the western Atlantic from the  Bahamas, the Cayman Islands, Haiti, U.S. Virgin Islands, Belize, Isla de Providencia (Colombia), and Santa Marta, Colombia (Böhlke and Chaplin 1993, J. Van Tassell pers. comm. 2011, R. Robertson pers. comm. 2014). It has an estimated area of occupancy (AOO) of 1,218 km<sup>2</sup> (calculated by clipping the distribution polygon to the WCMC 2013 coral layer and a zero to 10 m bathymetric layer from ETOPO).
useTrade: This species is not used.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures in place.

rationale: This widely distributed species can be abundant where it occurs in patch reefs or in the spur and groove zone on cave overhangs. It may be locally impacted by predation from the invasive lionfish in the Caribbean, however, this is not considered to be a major threat to its global population. Therefore, it is listed as Least Concern.
habitat: Priolepis hipoliti inhabits spur and groove or patch reefs between one to 27 m depth. It is usually found resting upside down under overhangs or in caves (Greenfield and Johnson 1999).
threats: It may be locally impacted by coral reef degradation, but this is not considered to be a major threat. It has been identified as a prey item of the invasive Lionfish in the Bahamas and Mexican Caribbean likely in the remainder of its greater Caribbean range (Green et al. 2012, Valdez-Moreno et al. 2012, Green and Cote 2014). This species is easily targeted by the lionfish given its small, shallow body and demersal habits (Green and Cote 2014). Due to the lionfish's ability to consume a variety of fishes smaller than 15 cm, both adults and juveniles of this species are likely consumed. In the Bahamas, a 65% decline in lionfish prey biomass over a period of two years was observed (species-specific data are not available at this time) (Green et al. 2012). However, this is not expected to impact its global population.
population: This species can be abundant in at least part of its range. In a study conducted off Belize and Honduras, it was one of the most abundant gobiid species collected, accounting for 8.9% of the total catch (Greenfield and Johnson 1999).
range: Priolepis hipoliti is distributed in the western Atlantic from Bermuda, southeast Florida, the Bahamas, in the Gulf of Mexico from the Florida Keys, Flower Garden Banks, Tuxpan (Mexico), and along northwestern Cuba, throughout the Caribbean, and along the Central and South American coast from Mexico to Arembepe, Brazil. It has also been recorded in the Aves Islands (Venezuela) (McEachran and Fechelm 2005, R. Robertson pers. comm. 2014).
useTrade: Priolepis hipoliti is not utilized.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures in place.

rationale: Halichoeres burekae is only known from three widely spaced coral reef localities in the Gulf of Mexico. It can be locally common in at least one locality, but uncommon in the other two. However, areas of suitable habitat are relatively small, few in number, and scattered. Its estimated area of occupancy (AOO) is 275 km², which meets the threshold for Endangered under criterion B2. It is under threat from the loss of coral reef habitat due to sedimentation and pollution off Veracruz. It is susceptible to predation by the invasive Lionfish, which now occurs throughout the entire range of this species. An overall 65% decline in prey biomass was directly observed over a period of two years in the Bahamas. However, species-specific decline nor generation length are available at this time. The species is therefore assessed as Endangered (EN B2ab(ii,iii)) with a recommendation to reduce pollution off Veracruz and conduct research on its life history and impact from the invasive Lionfish.
habitat: This species inhabits coral reef to depths of 24 m, but may occur as deep as 50 m. It is a planktivore. More information is needed on its biology and ecology.
threats:
The Veracruz reef system is threatened by heavy anthropogenic impacts such as accidental fuel spills, commercial shipping activity that enters directly through the marine protected area, and run-off contamination from heavy metals, faeces, fertilizers and pesticide pollutants (Ortiz-Lozano 2012). The Sistema Arrecifal Veracruzano is a national park, however there is no effective management plan in place and the Mexican government has been seeking to reduce the size of the protected area in order to expand the Port of Veracruz onto the reef area (Ortiz-Lozano et al. 2013). There have also been significant declines in Acroporid corals with no sign of recovery and a high prevalence of disease on stony corals (Rangel-Avalos et al. 2007). The coral in the Flower Garden Banks is in good condition (Hickerson et al. 2008). The status of coral on Alacranes is unknown, however, due to its offshore location, it is not expected to be influenced by the effects of pollution.

This species is a prey species of the invasive Lionfish (Pterois volitans) (L. Rocha pers. comm. 2014). Lionfish are currently increasing in all localities of its restricted range. This species is easily targeted by the lionfish given its small, shallow body and demersal habits (Green and Cote 2014). Due to the Lionfish's ability to consume a variety of fishes smaller than 15 cm, both adults and juveniles of this species are likely consumed. In the Bahamas, a 65% decline in Lionfish prey biomass over a period of two years was observed (species-specific data are not available at this time) (Green et al. 2012).
population: This species is relatively common on Alacranes Reef, where it forms small (15 individuals) to large (200 individuals) aggregations in depths from 2-25 m (Aguilar-Perrera and Tuz-Aulub 2009). It is uncommonly sighted in visual surveys conducted in Flower Gardens and it is likely that these populations are not reproductively viable due to less optimal habitat available. It is uncommon off Veracruz.
range:
This western Atlantic Ocean species is endemic to the Gulf of Mexico, where it has been recorded from shallow reefs off Veracruz (Mexico), the Flower Garden Banks National Marine Sanctuary, and Alacranes Reef (22°31’28N, 89°42’44W) off the northern Yucatan Peninsula (Aguilar-Perrera and Tuz-Aulub 2009). It has been recorded to 50 m depth, but occurs more commonly from 2-24 m.

Its estimated AOO is 275 km² (calculated by clipping the distribution polygon to the coral reef layer from WCMC 2013). Between 1965-1999 (34 years), a 17% decline in coral cover was directly observed off Veracruz (Jackson et al. 2014). There have been no significant observed declines in coral cover in Alacranes or Flower Gardens mostly due to their offshore location or lack of scientific data (Alacranes).
useTrade: This species is not utilized.
conservationActions:
There are no species specific conservation measures for this fish. However, its distribution lies mainly within marine protected areas. The Flower Garden Banks National Marine Sanctuary was designated in 1992 and is managed by the U.S. federal government. All types of fishing other than recreational hook and line fishing are outlawed, recreational scuba diving is permitted, and anchoring is illegal. Though the banks are in close proximity to intense activity from the oil and gas industry, there have been no known detrimental impacts. The coral reef ecosystem in the sanctuary is considered to be in good or excellent condition (Hickerson et al. 2008).

The Sistema Arrecifal Veracruzano has been designated as a national park since 1992 and a UNESCO Biosphere Reserve since 2006, however, there is no effective management plan in place. Furthermore, the Mexican government has been seeking to reduce the size of the protected area in order to expand the Port of Veracruz onto the reef area (Ortiz-Lozano et al. 2013). Similarly, the Alacranes Reef National Park was designated by UNESCO in 1994 and as a national park in 2000.

rationale: This species has a limited distribution and can be relatively common where it occurs over coral reef. Its estimated AOO is 875 km2, which meets the threshold for Vulnerable under B2. Direct observations show an approximate 15% decline in coral cover over a period of 41 years (1970-2011) in at least 92% of its overall range (Mexico and Belize). Coral reefs in the Honduran Bay Islands appear to be stable. There is currently no evidence that indicates its distribution is severely fragmented and it is known from more than 10 locations. Considering it only qualifies for one out of the minimum two required subcriteria, this species is listed as Near Threatened under B2b(iii).
habitat: It is found on coral heads and is a cleaner species. The largest recorded specimen is 2.8 cm SL.
threats: This species may be vulnerable to loss or degradation of coral habitat. Between 1970-2011 (41 years), an overall 59% decline in coral cover was directly observed in the Caribbean, which was caused by anthropogenic stressors, Diadema antillarum decline, and coral disease. Between 2000-2008, a 9% decline occurred on the Chinchorro Bank. Between 1970-2011, a 16.5% decline occurred off Belize (central barrier). Between 1987-2010, there was no significant change in coral cover off the Honduran Bay Islands (Jackson et al. 2014). The combined area of its range off Mexico and Belize is 809 km2 and the area off Honduras is 66 km2, therefore, coral habitat is known to be declining over at least 92% of its total range.
population: This species is relatively common within its habitat.
range: This species is distributed in the western Atlantic from Banco Chinchorro, Mexico to the Honduran Bay Islands (Randall and Colin 2009). Its depth ranges between one to 27 m. It has an estimated area of occupancy (AOO) of 875 km2 (calculated by clipping the distribution polygon to the WCMC 2013 coral layer and the zero to 50 m bathymetric layer from ETOPO). It has an estimated extent of occurrence (EOO) of 68,568 km2 (based on a minimum convex polygon drawn around the extent of its range on the coral reef layer).
useTrade: It is not known but could be used in the aquarium trade.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures in place. Additional research is needed into the possible impact of coral habitat loss on this species.

rationale: Pangshura tentoria is a widespread and common species which occurs in a number of major protected areas and not known to be subject to any significant declines of populations or available habitat. Trade is fairly limited relative to the large overall population size, and it remains relatively common over much of its range. It is therefore assessed as Least Concern.
habitat: Pangshura tentoria is primarily a riverine turtle, inhabiting small and large rivers; they bask on rocks and tree snags (Das 1991). Pangshura tentora occurs up to 80 m altitude in the terai of Nepal (Schleich and Kästle 2002). Adult females are predominantly herbivorous, males and juveniles are more carnivorous, taking a variety of freshwater invertebrates and possibly small fish (Das 1991). May consume large quantities of water plant pest species (Eichhornia, Pistia, Salvinia, etc.). Females may reach 23 cm carapace length (tentoria) / 27 cm (circumdata) / 20 cm (flaviventer), males remain much smaller (Das 1991). Average clutch size for ssp. tentoria is five eggs, range 3–6, and likely two clutches are produced per female annually (Singh 1985 in Das 1991). Subspecies circumdata produce clutches of on average six eggs (range 3–12) (Rao and Singh 1987), while flaviventer females produce clutches of 6–10 eggs (Moll 1987). Overall, age of maturity of is about 5–6 years; with a generation length estimate of about 20 years; longevity is not well known.
threats: Large specimens of Pangshura tentoria are occasionally exploited for consumption (Das 1991); P. tentoria was encountered in seven of 35 surveyed markets before 1983 (Moll 1983), but was not encountered in 61 markets surveyed in 1991–1993 (Choudhury and Bhupathy 1993). Modest numbers of juveniles are traded in the global pet trade. At least 52 live specimens, in three shipments, were reported as seized from illegal trade during the period 2000–2015 (CITES CoP17 Doc73). While habitat loss impacts such as pollution, reservoir construction, sand mining and agricultural conversion of riparian habitats likely affect individual populations, these have not been argued to represent significant threats for the species overall. Trade and seizures of subspecies circumdata have increased in recent years.
population: Pangshura tentoria is considered a very common species (Das 1991), noted as common in many areas of its range (Choudhury et al. 2000). Overall Pangshura tentoria continues to be considered of Least Concern in India (Participants Lucknow Red List Workshop 2005, Singapore Red List Workshop 2011) and as Near Threatened in Bangladesh (Rashid and Praschag pers. comm. at Singapore Red List Workshop 2011). Participants at the Singapore Red List Workshop (2018) agreed.
range:
Pangshura tentoria inhabits the lowlands of the Ganga, Brahmaputra, Mahanadi and Godavari River basins (Iverson 1992, Das 1995).

Pangshura t. tentoria inhabits the Mahanadi and Godavari River basins of Andhra Pradesh, Madhya Pradesh, Maharashtra, and Orissa and is thus endemic to India.

Pangshura t. circumdata inhabits the upper and central parts of the Ganga basin of southern Nepal and northern India (Madhya Pradesh, Rajasthan, Uttar Pradesh), and has also been reported from the Gambir River of Gujarat.

Pangshura t. flaviventer occurs in the northern tributaries and lower Ganga, from Nepal through Bihar, Uttar Pradesh, and West Bengal in India, to Bangladesh.

The subspecific identity of the form inhabiting the Brahmaputra is unclear (Das 1995: 130).
useTrade: This species is collected for both the domestic and international food markets and pet trade.
conservationActions:
Pangshura tentoria is included in CITES Appendix II, allowing international commercial trade in the species, provided such trade is not detrimental to the species, and subject to national trade legislation. It is apparently not listed in the Schedules of the Indian Wildlife (Protection) Act of 1972 (amended), though it may have been intended to be covered under Schedule I because tentoria and its subspecies were considered subspecies of Pangshura tecta at the time the law was implemented. Inclusion of Pangshura tentoria in one of the Schedules of the Indian Wildlife (Protection) Act should perhaps be considered (Appendix II).

Pangshura tentoria circumdata has been recorded from Katerniaghat Wildlife Sanctuary and Dudhwa Tiger Reserve in Uttar Pradesh, India (Hanfee, 1999) and the Chambal River Sanctuary, while P. t. flaviventer occurs in probably all protected areas along the main stem of the Brahmaputra (P. Praschag pers. comm. 2005). The subspecies P. t. tentoria, however, has not been confirmed from any protected areas (Participants Lucknow Red List Workshop 2005).

Taxonomic re-analysis of the subspecies and river basin populations (especially of flaviventer in apparent sympatry with circumdata, and identity of the Brahmaputra population) is highly desirable.

Status surveys throughout its range, with emphasis on protected areas, are desired, as is monitoring of key populations. Detailed natural history studies would be welcome. Safeguarding populations in effectively protected areas continues to be the main conservation objective.

rationale: This species is listed as Near Threatened in view of the general prevalence of ‘old’ and ‘new’ threats, often increasing in intensity, the fact that all estimates so far point to overall population decline, and the species occurring at low densities in most areas. It is possible that the decline approaches the threshold of 30% over three generations (set at 21 years), but available data are of insufficient reliability and area coverage.
habitat:
The Siberian Ibex primarily occupies mountainous regions from 500 to-5,500 m asl in rocky terrain and open alpine meadows and crags, seeking out lower elevations during the winter (Fedosenko and Blank 2001). In the completely snowed in valleys of the Himalaya, however, ibex remain in high elevations during winter to feed on emergent vegetation in the avalanche chutes and windblown crests, and also digging through softer snow of the higher elevations. They descend to the lower valley bottoms to take advantage of the spring thaw, but ascend to the highest ridgelines during the peak of summer (Schaller 1977, Bhatnagar 1997). Ibex occupies precipitous habitats in a range of environments from deserts, low mountains and foothills, to high mountain ridges. Siberian Ibex can also be found in areas with canyons, rocky outcrops, and steep ‘escape’ terrain far from high mountains (Fedosenko and Blank 2001, Reading et al. 2007, Peterson 2016, Bragin et al. 2017). The species rarely enters forest zones, but on a hot day does prefer shaded areas, or even small pockets of pastures near glaciers. Ibex tend to remain near steep, escape terrain (Bhatnagar 1997; Fedosenko and Blank 2001; Reading et al. 2007). In the Pin Valley National Park in India, over 90% of the over 800 ibex sightings were within 100 m from ‘escape terrain’ (Bhatnagar 1997). Females tend to retreat into the security of cliffs for parturition in May-June (Schaller 1977).

Ibex live in small groups that vary considerably in size, sometimes forming herds of over 100 animals, but more typically averaging 6-30 animals, depending on the region (Reading et al. 1995, 1997, 1999b; Fedosenko and Blank 2001; Singh et al. 2010). They spend the day in alternating periods of activity and rest, having a bimodal pattern through much of the year. In winter, ibex in the Himalaya tend to have a distinct unimodal activity peak towards noon, while resting on or near cliffs from evening until the next morning (Fox et al. 1992, Bhatnagar and Manjrekar 2015).

Ibex shows little sexual segregation throughout the year, except the period between parturition (around June) and autumn (November) (Reading et al. 2007; Bhatnagar and Manjrekar 2015). Ibex in an area of rocky outcrops in the Mongolian Gobi Desert displayed no segregation between sexes and similar sized mean annual home ranges using minimum convex polygons (MCPs) of 42 km2 for females (n = 5) and 39 km2 for males (n = 4) (Reading et al. 2007). A study on ranging patterns of ibex in the Indian Himalaya (2 adult males and 3 females) shows that the mean annual home range (MCPs) of males (44 km2) was almost double that of females (20 km2) (Bhatnagar and Manjrekar 2015). Ibex used extremely small ranges on lower, south facing slopes with early sprout during the spring (<3 km2), expanding to larger ranges in summer and autumn, but again confining to small ranges during winter (5-10 km2). Daily movements of ibex were highest during the summer flush when they traversed over a km during a day to take advantage of forage quality, but were confined to barely a 300-400 meters during winter and spring due to limited usable patches (Bhatnagar and Manjrekar 2015).

Ibex are primarily grazers with herbs as well as subshrubs and shrubs such as Eurotia sp., Rosa sp. and Ephedra sp. contributing significantly to their diet (Manjrekar 1997, Fedosenko and Blank 2001, Bagchi et al. 2004, Tumursukh 2015).

Females gestate for 170-180 days (Heptner et al. 1961) and usually give birth to one, sometimes two, kids in the spring. The animals reach sexual maturity at 18 months for females and 30 months for males, although usually only older males mate (Fedosenko and Blank 2001). Siberian Ibex can live up to 16-17 years (Heptner et al. 1961, Fedosenko and Blank 2001).
threats:
Throughout its range, local people hunt ibex for subsistence use because they traditionally provide an important supplementary food for local people. Poaching also occurs in some areas by military personnel, road maintenance workers, and others, especially in areas accessible by vehicle (Schaller et al. 1987). Additional threats to ibex include competition with livestock for food and habitat, and in some areas by predators. As a result of these threats, some populations have declined significantly, especially in regions with dense human populations.

In 2007, producers of wool products in Nepal began marketing a product they termed “yangir”, which they claimed originated from wild, hunted Capra sibirica. (Some hair fibers from C. sibirica are quite fine, and potentially may be used for high-quality wool). At least one importer based in Germany was marketing these products as high-end, specialty scarves. As of this writing (early 2020), the origin of these products (and whether they indeed came from C. sibirica) had not yet been determined, but were still being advertised on the internet as coming from ibex, stating that annually 1500 kg of the wool are produced world-wide (www.acitac.com/materialien/faserkunde/yangir.html). This would require the harvest of a considerable number of animals. Domestic hunting might provide the raw material. Trophy hunting programs harvest only a few animals/year and are unlikely to be the source of a commercially marketed wool product. However, so far interest in ibex wool at local level is unknown and it seems Central Asia is not (yet) a supplier (Michel unpubl. data). If Capra sibirica were being poached specifically to feed this market, formerly stable populations could quickly become threatened.

In Kazakhstan, Kyrgyzstan, Mongolia, Pakistan, Russia, Tajikistan and Uzbekistan Siberian Ibex are harvested in trophy hunting programs. Trophy hunting targets only males above a certain age, and so direct impacts on targeted population size likely remain negligible, but poorly regulated trophy hunting can have many negative consequences (Reading and Amgalanbaatar 2016), including an effect on the sex and age composition of populations as reported from Kyrgyzstan (Michel and Rosen 2016). The potential of causing evolutionary effects is low as long as hunter harvest only a minor portion of the males. Bans on trophy hunting and importation of hunting trophies risk removing incentives to prevent poaching and might increase human-caused mortality of ibex.

Climate change likely poses new threats by altering habitat quality, in particular affecting water availability, vegetation composition and phenology as well as causing changes in land-use.

In Afghanistan, it seems that prior to the Soviet invasion, Siberian Ibex was abundant and hunted throughout its range by local tribesmen. The impact of hunting was believed to be limited, in some areas due to customary regulations (Michel unpubl. data, based information from traditional hunters 2009). Currently hunting is formally banned, but poaching is still a major threat to the species, especially where new roads increase accessibility and modern weapons improve efficiency, in particular where military personnel and other armed forces are involved. Poaching became of greater concern in Wakhan National Park (i.e. the district of Wakhan), where border guards and police presence has increased (Ostrowski pers. comm. 2019).

In China, the species is classified as a Category I Protected Wild Animal Species under the Wild Animal Protection Law (Wang 1998). Poaching might now pose a minor threat, as the government has confiscated most guns from pastoralists living near ibex habitat, although some poaching by police and/or military no doubt continues. Competition with livestock may occur.

In India, region-wide threat assessments are scarce. Ghoshal et al. (2015) report illegal hunting by migratory laborers and migratory herders as one of the most important threats across the state of Himachal Pradesh, followed by subsistence hunting by local people and competition with migratory livestock for fodder. Increased grazing and disturbance from livestock are apparent in some areas (Fox et al. 1986, 1994; Pandey, 1993). Livestock grazing may not necessarily indicate competition, as was evident from summer grazing by local herders in Pin Valley; however, large herds of migratory herders were certainly a threat (Bhatnagar et al. 2000, Bagchi et al. 2004). The fact that ibex can utilize rugged habitats have probably allowed them to linger precariously in parts of Himachal Pradesh with heavy grazing by migratory herds of livestock (Ghoshal et al. 2015). The level of poaching is extremely low in the Buddhist dominated areas of India (Spiti and Ladakh). Heavy military presence along the disputed border between India and Pakistan can cause considerable disturbance to the species on both sides of the border, including the presence of border fencing. In fact, the ‘highest battlefield in the world’ around the Siachen glacier, contested between India and Pakistan, is surrounded by prime ibex habitat of the Karakorum, but is subjected to considerable military activity.

In Pakistan, poaching for food, heavy military presence on the Indian and Afghanistan borders, and competition for food with livestock are threats to Siberian Ibex.

In Mongolia, transformation of ibex habitat for mining might be one of the most important emerging threats to the conservation of this species (see Tumursukh et al. 2015). The impact of trophy hunting on ibex populations remains uncertain (Lkhagvasuren et al. 2016). Other important threats to the species include grazing competition and disturbance from livestock, and poaching (Mallon et al. 1997, Clark et al. 2006). Ibex is probably less affected than argali (Ovis ammon) by poaching and competition with livestock, because of the more precipitous and hence less accessible terrain it occupies, yet both probably negatively affect the species (Mallon et al. 1997, Clark et al. 2006). A recent study by Odonjavkhlan (2018) did not find evidence for an impact of livestock grazing on habitat use by ibex in Tost Tosunbumba Nature Reserve. Tumursukh (2013) found evidence for competition between ibex and goats/sheep for forage; however, he did not find any evidence for demographic impacts from this competition. Illegal and unsustainable hunting for meat, trophies and skins remains a threat (Wingard and Zahler 2006), although habitat degradation through grazing by increasing livestock numbers and competition for pasture and water may constitute threats in some areas (Reading et al. 2006b) and increasing resource extraction and mining activities may also result in habitat loss and degradation. Harsh winter weather conditions can also severely affect population sizes locally (Clark et al. 2006).

In Kazakhstan, Kyrgyzstan, Tajikistan and Uzbekistan the species is hunted by local people based on permit systems, but with a large unreported and illegal take. Informal hunting still seems to exceed official quotas in these countries, although the quotas for domestic hunters have not always appeared sustainable. Kyrgyzstan since 2017 has applied temporary hunting moratoria in several provinces, the effect of which is not yet evident.

In Russia, although hunted legally under license, many are shot illegally and in large numbers.
population:
No rigorously derived population estimates exist for Siberian Ibex in any range state, although Harris et al. (2009) and Lkhagvasuren et al. (2016) provide population estimates for most of Mongolia in 2009. Thus, the total population number provided here is a rough guess. Summarizing all available guestimates for the range states the total population size likely would be in the range of 170,000 to 250,000 animals (102,000 to 150,000 mature individuals).

In Afghanistan, the Siberian Ibex was considered abundant throughout its range prior to the late 1970s and a series of wars. Shank et al. (1977) estimated that around 5,000 animals used the Ajar Valley Reserve seasonally during the 1970s; this population is likely much smaller now (C. Shank pers. comm. 2007). More than 4,000 were believed to inhabit the Pamir alone. Their present status in the Pamir is unknown, but they are known to persist in reasonably large numbers throughout the ranges of the Wakhan Corridor. There in 2011 WCS recorded 2,069 animals in a direct count (1.6 per km²); in 2015, the double observer method yielded an estimate of 740 ±226 (2.2 per km²) (Z. Moheb pers. comm. 2017) and 753 ±267 (2.2 per km²) in 2018 (Ostrowski pers. comm. 2020). The Siberian Ibex occurs along the Panj River across most of Badakhshan Province, but in some districts is exposed to illegal overhunting and population numbers are unknown (Moheb et al. 2018).

There is no overall population estimate in China. The population in the Tian Shan had been guessed at 40,000-50,000 individuals (Wang 1998). Wu et al. (2015) estimate a density of 1.54 (± 0.23) per km² in the Tien Shan mountains south of Urumqi. Densities in other areas are relatively low. Rough guesses of ibex numbers in the Bei Mountains (northern Gansu) are between 3,000 and 4,000 individuals. The species has almost disappeared in the Daqin Mountains (Gao et al. 2011). The species is listed as “Endangered” in the China Red Data Book of Endangered Animals (Wang 1998).

In India, earlier population estimates include a minimum of 6,000 in Ladakh (Fox et al. 1991a) and perhaps another 4,000 on the south side of the main Himalaya in Jammu and Kashmir and Himachal Pradesh, and in the Pir Panjal range of Himachal Pradesh (Fox et al. 1992). A total of up to 15,000 ibex was estimated by Johnsingh, Mishra and Bhatnagar (1997) in ca 40,000 km² of potential habitat based on rough extrapolations. Counts of ibex in protected areas include 330 in the Kanji-Boodkharbu, 225 in Lungnag, 250 in Rangdum, and 174 in Rizong Wildlife Sanctuaries (Jammu and Kashmir) (Fox et al. 1991a), and 174 in the Pin Valley National Park (Himachal Pradesh) where Pandey (1993) estimated a density of 2.3 ibex/km² in 1989 and Johnsingh et al. (1997) at a lower value of 1.2 ibex/km². More recently Suryawanshi et al. (2012) estimate a density of 0.37 ibex/km² or 184 (± 40) ibex in 497 km² in Pin Valley National Park; a density of 0.11 ibex/km or 45 (±13) in 411 km² of Kibber Wildlife Sanctuary and a density of 0.14 ibex/km² or 30 (±14) in 219 km² of Lossar area of Spiti Valley, Himachal Pradesh. Over the past 10 years, these populations have been monitored using similar protocol and the population trends are stable (Suryawanshi, unpublished data). A recent occupancy survey by Ghoshal et al. (2017) across the state of Himachal Pradesh found that ibex occupy an estimated 8,915 km². They found no evidence of range expansion or contraction in the Himachal Pradesh region between 1992 and 2015. Given these figures, we suspect that total population might not be more than 15,000.

As reported by Weinberg et al. (1997), the total number of ibex in the former Soviet Republics of Central Asia (as well as in adjacent Russia) was estimated at between 100,000 to 110,000 animals. Most of these occurred in Kyrgyzstan and Tajikistan (ca 70,000) and Kazakhstan (ca. 17,000) with far fewer (8,000 to 9,000) in southern Siberia (3,000 to 3,500 in the Altai, 2,500 in Tannu Ola mountains of Tuva, 1,500 in Western Sayan and 2,000 to 2,500 in Eastern Sayan) and Uzbekistan (2,400). In Kazakhstan, the official numbers reported by the Provincial Territorial Inspection Services for Forestry and Wildlife of the Ministry of Agriculture (A. Muzbay pers. comm. 2019) during the period 2014-2018 varied between 16,582 and 22,700 (average 20,500). These variations may reflect differences in reporting or methods rather than actual fluctuations of the population size. In Kyrgyzstan, officially reported numbers for the years 2000 – 2013 vary between 34,000 in 2009 and 73,000 in 2000, and are not always fully consistent (summarized information from National Statistics Committee and State Agency for Forestry and Environmental Protection, Z. Kubanychbekov pers. comm. 2019); the most recent official figure was 41,463 in 2018 (Press Service of the State Agency on Forestry and Environmental Protection, 2019 quoted at https://eco.akipress.org/news:1562027). The abundance varies. There are hunting concessions with little livestock grazing and few protected areas (e.g. Ala-Arch National Park and Sarychat-Ertash Strictly Protected Area) with high numbers and densities. In the overall mountain landscape, which is intensively used for livestock grazing and where poaching is widespread, numbers are very low. The population size in the Pamirs and Pamiro-Alay in Tajikistan are unknown, but the species was considered common, especially in the western part of the Pamirs (Weinberg et al. 1997). Numbers had declined during and after the civil war in Tajikistan in the 1990s and recovered only locally. The total potentially suitable area in Tajikistan is approx. 70,000 km²; if applying the lower density margin (0.2/km²) from the site estimates below the total ibex population size might be 14,000 animals (own guess Michel, 2019). Considering that large areas are intensively used for grazing and poaching impact has reduced population sizes, this figure might be more realistic than higher estimates of up to 25,000 (Kh. Karimov pers. comm. 2019). In Uzbekistan, the population might still be in the range of 2,000-2,500 animals, although the southern part of the Hissar Range in Surkhandarya Province has not been surveyed for the last two decades (E. Bykova pers. comm. 2019). Thus, despite local declines the overall population size seems to be still similar as reported in Shackleton (1997) with no detectable overall trend, but possibly declines at least in Kyrgyzstan and Tajikistan. However, it is not clear if this apparently stable or slightly declining population size reflects the real situation or continuity in formal reporting by state agencies and hunting organizations. The continuing prevalence of poaching across Central Asia combined with an increase in the intensity and area covered by livestock grazing in mountainous rangelands over the last two decades leads us to suspect an overall more substantial decline in population size than reflected in official numbers. This suspected decline is also supported by site-level estimates in areas with different management regimes

Few site level estimates exist for the Central Asia region. Jumabay-Uulu (2013) estimated a density of 0.67 ibex/km² in 1,341 km² of Sarychat-Ertash Nature Reserve in Kyrgyzstan. Recent surveys (2018) by Khanyari (unpublished data) using the double-observer survey method put the estimates in this area at 2.26 ibex/km². Numbers in community-based conservancies in the Bartang valley, Wakhan and Northern Alichur range of Tajikistan have been stable or increasing between 2009 and 2019 with densities varying between 0.19 and 1.42 animals per km² conservancy area and an absolute number of up to 2,300 over an area of 2,250 km² (unpublished data of ANCOT, 2019). Michel and Muratov (2010) reported direct counts of 2,476 animals in 8,174 km² surveyed area of the eastern Pamirs of Tajikistan (0.30 ibex per km² surveyed area with substantial variation between areas). Point counts in two sections of this area in 2013 yielded estimates of 0.34 animals per km² in an unmanaged area and 0.57 animals per km² in a game management area (unpublished analysis of data of ANCOT by Michel). 

The Mongolian Red Data Book 1987 (Shagdarsuren et al. 1987), stated that 1,000 individuals inhabited western Khövsgöl alone, and a total of 80,000 animals occurred in Mongolia in the mid-1980s (Fedosenko and Blank 2001). Mallon et al. (1997) stated that ibex numbers declined since that peak estimate of 80,000 due to exploitation, habitat degradation and competition for resources (Schaller 1994, 1995, 1998). Lkhagvasuren et al. (2016) estimated a total of 36,018 (13,840–43,873) ibex across Mongolia. This is much lower than the 80,000 ibex estimated in mid-1980s. In the Khohk Serkh Reserve in the High Altai, the population was estimated at 1,000 in 1979 by Dzieciolowski et al. (1980) and at 1,200 by des Clers (1985). Tulgat and Schaller (1992) estimated 600 ibex in the Great Gobi Strictly Protected Area. In 1989, in a 200 km² study area west of Tsogt in the Altai, Schaller et al. (1994) counted 337 ibex, and estimated there may have been a total of up to 450 animals. Reading et al. (1997) recorded 1,218 ibex in 623 km² of Gobi Gurvan Saikhan National Conservation Park (Reading et al. 1999b). Tumursukh et al. (2015) estimate a density of 0.75 ibex/km² or 1,051 (±196) in 1,400 km² of the Tost Mountains of South Gobi, which were later declared Tost-Tosumbumba Nature Reserve. Few other rigorously derived estimates of population numbers exist for other parts of Mongolia.

Siberian Ibex is widely distributed over northern Pakistan, but is only locally abundant in the northern part of the country. Hess (1986) found the highest density in northern Pakistan to be in the area along the Barpu Glacier (Gilgit District) with 1.2 to 1.6 animals/km² (n = 194-270 animals, area surveyed = 164 km2). Wegge (1988) estimated that >2,000 ibex lived in the Khunjerab NP, at a slightly lower density of ca 1.0 ibex/km². In many areas the species had densities of only 0.1 to 0.3/km² as in the Shinghai Valley, Gilgit District (n = 15-50 animals, area surveyed = 176 km², Hess, 1986). Within the Gilgit District, Siberian ibex was clearly rarer in the southern than in the northern part. The reasons for this may be that compared to northern areas, elevations in the south are generally lower, there are higher densities of humans using alpine pastures, and there are smaller distances between villages. The census of the NWFP Forest Department (NWFP, 1992) gives 2,545 animals for the whole province; in Azad Jammu and Kashmir, a total of 375 were estimated (Qayyum, 1986, 87). Recent surveys by Khan et al. (2015) estimated a total of 899 ibex in a survey area of 1,895 km² of Khunjerab National Park. They encountered the highest densities of ibex in the Muztagh-Taxkorgan region with an estimated 1.17 ibex per km². Din et al. (2011) counted 429 ibex in 1,022 km² of northern Chitral (Torkhow valley). Rahman and Din (2016) in Chipursan Valley (Hunza) recorded 2,085 ibex (0.26/km²). Ali et al. (2007) counted 122 ibex in the Neelum Valley of Azad Kashmir. During 2010-2011 in Nagar Valley of Gilgit-Baltistan Ali et al. (2015) counted 478 in winter and 456 in spring, leading to density estimates of 0.33 and 0.32 per km² respectively. Khan et al. (2014) reported 2,777 ibexes from the whole of Gilgit Baltistan, while annual surveys of ibex in central Karakoram National Park suggest numbers to be around 2,500 ibex.
range:
This species inhabits the mountain ranges, isolated mountains, and rocky outcrops of central and northeastern Afghanistan, China (northwestern tip of Gansu, western Inner Mongolia, Xinjiang, possibly Tibet on its border with Xinjiang, Schaller 1998), northwestern India (Himalaya of Jammu and Kashmir, Ladakh and Himachal Pradesh), southern and eastern Kazakhstan, Kyrgyzstan, Mongolia (Altai, Gobi-Altai, Khangai, and Sayan Mountains, as well as in the southeast), northern Pakistan, Russia (southern Siberia, southern Tuva, and the Altai Mountains), Tajikistan and northeastern Uzbekistan (west Tian Shan) (Shackleton 1997, Grubb 2005, Harris et al. 2009).

In Afghanistan, Siberian Ibex were historically found in steep habitat throughout the Afghan Hindu Kush and its outlying ranges (e.g., Spinghar, Kohe Baba, Safed Koh, Feroz Koh, Nuristan), but current distribution is not known. Its occurrence has been confirmed since 2000 in suitable habitat throughout the Afghan Pamir and along the Panj River of north-eastern Badakhshan, in particular in Wakhan, Ishkashem, Zebak, Rushan and Darvaz districts (Simms et al. 2014, Z. Moheb pers. comm. 2017, Moheb et al. 2018).

In China, Siberian Ibex occur primarily in the mountains surrounding Xinjiang, but also in those of extreme northern Gansu, and Inner Mongolia. Populations are relatively widespread in western Xinjiang (Abudoukadi’er 2003) in the mountains around the Dzungarian Basin, including the mountains along the border with Kazakhstan from south of the Irtysh River, through the Kok Shaal Tau Mountains along the border with Kyrgyzstan and into the Pamir along the border with Tajikistan, Afghanistan and Pakistan, and also throughout the Tian Shan ranges. Populations occur along the Sino-Mongolia border in the Baytik Mountains (Xinjiang), in the Mazongshan area of northern Gansu, and as far east as the Daqinshan of central Inner Mongolia (Wang 1998). Slightly separated from these are populations in the Altai Mountains in northern Xinjiang, along China’s borders with Mongolia, and Russia.

The Siberian Ibex has a widespread distribution in northeastern and eastern Uzbekistan, Tajikistan, Kyrgyzstan, Kazakhstan, and southern Siberia, where it occupies precipitous habitats in a range of environments from hot deserts, low mountains and foothills, to high mountain ridges. It is found throughout the ranges of the Pamiro-Alay, Pamir, Tian Shan, Dzungarian Alatau, Altai, and Tuva Mountains, as well as the western and eastern Sayan (Weinberg et al. 1997; Fedosenko 2001). The species occurs in mountainous areas with sufficient rugged escape terrain and suitable pockets of grazing habitat, but is missing in the wide mountain valleys and plateaus intensively used for livestock grazing.

In Mongolia, Siberian Ibex are patchily distributed in rugged terrain throughout the western half of the country, and in central and south-central Mongolia to the trans-Siberian railway line (Ulaanbaatar to Sainshand) (Dulamtseren 1970, 1977; Mallon et al. 1997; Clark et al. 2006; Harris et al. 2009). More specifically, ibex inhabit the Altai, Hangai, and Gobi Altai Mountain Ranges (Bannikov 1954, Dulamtseren 1970, Sokolov and Orlov 1980, Mallon 1985, Schaller 1994, Mallon et al. 1997, Fedosenko and Blank 2001, Clark et al. 2006, Harris et al. 2009). They also occur in the Sayan Mountains near the Russian border west of Lake Hovsgol and in scattered populations in the small mountains in the Transaltai Gobi and in canyons, rocky outcrops, and other rugged terrain throughout the Gobi Desert (Bannikov 1954; Dulamtseren 1977; Reading et al. 1995, 1999a, 1999b; Mallon et al. 1997; Fedosenko and Blank 2001; Clark et al. 2006; Harris et al. 2009). A small, introduced population survives in the Bogd Uul Mountains just outside of Ulaanbaatar (Mallon et al. 1997, Clark et al. 2006). The largest number of ibex occurs in the Altai and western Hangai Mountains (Harris et al. 2009). Populations continue to become increasingly fragmented, especially in central and southeastern Mongolia (Schaller 1994, Clark et al. 2006, Harris et al. 2009). A long-term research project on ibex ecology is being conducted in northern Ikh Nart Nature Reserve in northern Dornogobi Aimag (Reading et al. 2006b, 2007; Singh et al. 2010; Peterson 2016; Bragin et al. 2017; Otgonbayar et al. 2017).

In India, the Siberian Ibex occurs in the Himalayan regions of Jammu and Kashmir, in the Karakorum, Zanskar and Trans-Himalayan region of Ladakh and in the Trans Himalayan and Himalayan regions of Himachal Pradesh, as far east as the Sutlej river (Fox 1987; Fox et al. 1992; Gaston et al. 1981; Pandey 1993). The species occurs in the western half of Ladakh, in the Shyok Valley (Nubra region) of northern Ladakh, along the Ladakh Range, and along both sides of the main Himalayan Range eastward to Shingo La (Fox et al. 1991a, 1992; Mallon 1991; Bhatnagar and Manjrekar 2015). Its occurrence is very sparse east of the Zanskar River, a tributary of the Indus. It is present along the southern side of the Himalaya in Jammu and Kashmir from the Zoji La eastwards to Himachal Pradesh, where it occurs throughout much of Lahul and Spiti, in the upper Beas and Parbati catchments, and Kinnaur in the east, primarily on the right bank of the Sutlej river (Fox et al. 1992; Pandey 1993; Bhatnagar 2003; Bhatnagar and Manjrekar 2015; Ghoshal et al. 2017).

In  Pakistan,  the population of Himalayan Ibex is currently concentrated within the Karakoram Range, especially in the Districts of Hunza (Gojal Valley), Nagar (Hopper and Hisper), Shigar (Basha and Braldu) and Ghanche (Hushey and Kandey) (Khan et al. 2014; Ali et al. 2015; Raza et al. 2015).
